justifications.2: While very smooth and natural-sounding, its direct, conversational tone is slightly less formal than other options, making it feel more like spoken than written fluency.
justifications.3: This is the most concise option, and while it is generally fluent, the final clause feels slightly abrupt compared to the more developed conclusions of the other candidates.
justifications.4: This candidate is the most fluent due to its sophisticated sentence structure and professional vocabulary, creating a polished and seamless flow from start to finish.

justifications.3: This candidate is the least coherent because its third-person framing feels impersonal and its conclusion is a weak observation rather than a strong, logically connected final point.
justifications.4: The structure is very logical and easy to follow, but it is slightly less detailed than the top-ranked candidate, making the logical connections a little less explicit.

title: A1_Q04_Accuracy

justifications.1: This text accurately captures all key points from the original—insightful feedback, falling motivation, and decent work—without introducing contradictory information.
justifications.2: This text is inaccurate because it adds the unsupported claims that the feedback is "consistently" provided and "significantly contributing," which are not mentioned in the original.
justifications.3: This text accurately restates all the factual information from the original, including the quality of feedback, the decline in motivation, and the decent work quality.
justifications.4: This text introduces inaccuracies by claiming the feedback is "consistently" provided and adds "significant value," neither of which is supported by the original text.
